 "I have lived a rogue's legacy..."	  SO MANY BABIES!	 So you're reading a review about Rogue Legacy? Odds are you either are coming to see if the hype around this game is warranted, or you've seen it was on sale and need that one last push to convince you that your purchase won't be in vain. While a bit lengthy, this review holds everything you could ever want to know before buying. WELL LET ME TELL YOU!!! This game is by far one of the most fun games I've purchased in a long while. I'll start with a synopsis of the game's plot, followed by the pros and cons of the game, and end it with an official rating and some inside info on gameplay.  Just scroll to the end and find my header titled "Gameplay" if all you want to know is "gameplay mechanics please, I don't need story info".	  Synopsis	  You are the heir to a throne occupied by a king who has fallen ill. To what, you don't entirely know. The king has set out on a quest to remedy himself by venturing in to a castle that has been rumored to be haunted for years on the outskirts of his land. Within this castle is the key to curing all sickness. If a hero proves himself worthy to battle through the arduous citadel, they will find themselves with the ultimate power to cure themselves of any ailment. Your father has disappeared. It was rumored he found himself the treasure within and decided to stay with his new found riches. Others believe he fell to the beasts that inhabit the dangerous depths. Regardless of his fate, this prompts your brother, the antagonist of the story, to begin his own journey into the castle and claim the fortune for himself. You play as a generation of heroes, all dedicated to saving the king, and rescuing your brother who also has appeared to be lost. Throughout your exploration of the castle, you stumble across various journal entries, chronicling your brothers advancements. I won't reveal the ending, but I will hint that the castle's riches are far more evil than any monster ever could be. As you begin your journey you find that the castle is most certainly under some type of spell... Every time a traveler enters the cold, unwelcoming halls, the rooms are randomized entirely. No floor plan is ever the same, causing confusion and plenty of surprises for any weary guest. Being a fortress for countless foes inhabiting the keep, your only reference is a map you create as you navigate each room. Moving from area to area, you find that the castle leads out to a haunted forest, a miasma of ghouls, and a crypt of darkness. Of course there is a mighty enemy that dominates each territory. These boss-like creatures are found out eventually to be previous explorers who have fallen victim to the castle's ultimate secret. The further your travels take you, the more accomplished you feel each time. But at what cost? At the end of each life, you reawaken as new kin. A son or daughter to the previous explorer's family. Countless years pass, and you find that entire generations of warriors are dedicated to a pointless cause it would feel. Will your efforts prove fruitless? Will the castle's secrets finally be unlocked? What of the long lost king, and your traitor of a brother? Spoilers:  Play the game. It takes less than 20 hours to beat it no matter how new you are to it. You don't need spoilers <3	  Pros	 - Every new life leads to a highly randomized generation of soldiers, ready to fight your fight. This means that you will be able to constantly explore new play styles, receive new perks, and have a great time laughing at some of the unfortunate traits you receive. - The replay value of this game is through the roof. It's never the same, meaning each playthrough yields a new experience. - New Game + mode is exceptional. Like most games, there are new items, harder enemies, and even the storyline changes in minor ways. - The traits each character inherits that causes them to be unique, on top of their abilities their class grants them, leads to a fantastic character selection that makes each run memorable.  Cons	 - Many have reviewed this game to say that it is too difficult. I will not disagree with the thought that it is difficult, however, I will counter the argument with this: Once you get the momentum rolling, and build your character up a bit, the difficulty is something you enjoy and crave. Building your characters up is far more enjoyable with a real challenge before you. The difficulty that crushes so many is only temporary, as most will not play past the first hour due to frustration. - One major drawback of the game is that the skill tree is too limited and feels pointless at times. Once you've unlocked everything, you spend the rest of the time building small things like health and defense. You no longer have any real goal to aim for, you're simply buffing up your character. This occurs approximately 14-15 hours in, usually just before you defeat the penultimate boss, or clear the third area. A shame as new game + offers so much, yet leaves the skill tree lacking.  Gameplay/Rating	  Controls/Movement	 The game's controls are a bit difficult. As simple as they are, you'll find yourself going out of your way to execute a much more difficult approach to combat, rather than the intended one. An example of this is the "downstrike" ability. You should have the ability to jump over an enemy, and attack below you. However, the attack is too fast, and you end up hurting yourself, by being susceptible to enemies. Instead, now you'll learn that it's best to jump around all over place, narrowly avoiding attacks, and attacking from the side, to avoid damage. Movement does feel very fluid despite its speed, and you are able to manipulate your character well. The additional perks of certain traits lends itself greatly to gameplay, as some characters have the ability to go where others cannot, some are not knocked back by hits, and some are able to send enemies flying.  Items/Skills/Stats	 Cellar Door Games outdid themselves with the items and skills in this game. The various weapons you can find, equipment you can earn, runes that will allow for special techniques or perks, and items that can assist you (or one in particular that horribly ruins you), are all brilliantly put together in this game. As said before, the only area where they fall short, is the stat system. Once you've unlocked everything in the skill tree, you are left to adding to stats while you yearn for more unlockables. The character system that has you choosing between being "The One" and going on a Tron-esque journey into the grid, or having insatiable bowels that cannot stop playing you the song of its people, helps really flesh out this game and give you a feel of infinite scenarios/builds.  Rating/Recommendation On a scale of 0-10 (keeping it simple), I'll give this game a fantastic 9/10. I highly recommend this game to anyone who has even gotten this far in the review. Trust me, it is extremely deserving of your time. Cellar Door Games has created a fantastic way to expend your time. A few honorable mentions are that this game does a great job of helping you truly appreciate the story... The tutorial portion of the game ends up being the last path you take before the end of the game. The dialogue is fantastic and makes you laugh from to time, and of the last statements by the last boss... "Truly I have lived a rogue's legacy"... it definitely struck me. This game is fantastic. I will find myself playing it again and again, restarting a character or continuing off of an accomplished one. Please enjoy this, and see what all the hype is about. Would I invest my time in writing so much if I didn't think this game was freaking amazing?! Thanks for reading. The fact that you did means you and I both are great at wasting time.

Posted: June 22, 2015
												Truth be told, I am not a huge fan of Roguelike games on a whole. Despite their mechanical purity and focus on strong gameplay, they often suffer from poor level design and a lack of emotional connection or progression. Rogue Legacy, however, manages to subvert the latter in a very intriguing way, even if I feel that many of the more negative trappings of Roguelike games haunt this title.The game continues to suffer from the poor level design of its contemporaries. Being a Metroidvania inspired title, with a massive vania and a small sobbing Metroid being dragged along with it, this isn't as big of an issue as it could be. But in a genre which so clearly has great level design laid out for it, it would've easily been possible to make this game have fantastic level design, due to the way it randomizes levels. At current, it has large amounts of enemy spam and doesn't really let you take advantage of your characters' particular abilities very well, aside from the base core mechanics.Unlike other Metroidvania titles, this game doesn't introduce new weapons or game mechanics as you progress through the game, but linear upgrades like higher HP stats, strength, and different classes whom usually have a unique ability not directly related to combat or movement, and shuffled stats. The game's character progression is relatively weak, is what I'm saying.But despite suffering from weak character progression and poor level design, this game has a certain permanence to your actions which other roguelikes don't. Your upgrades and unlocks stay with you as you play. Even with what is ostensibly the game's prestige mode, old upgrades and traits are kept and even enhanced. It culminates in a very enjoyable experience where you never necessarily feel like you've 'lost' much outside of the dungeons resetting, and you can pick up the game and continue right from where you left off again.In terms of game design, this is a rather poor title, but it participates in filling the niche of a more replayable game following the core concepts of Metroidvania style action platforming. A niche which was previously very empty.If the idea of a Metroidvania game which focuses on replayability sounds good to you, even if it has fairly poor level design and a progression system that leaves me lukewarm to it, it's very much so worth a try.I look forward to seeing the future offerings of Cellar Door Games. It's rumored that they're planning to start work on a Rogue Legacy sequel in the future, to which I would say that it should basically be this, with a more varied progression system featuring more substantial changes to movement mechanics and weapons, along with more stark level design, potentially killing the 'castle' segments altogether.But as it stands, this game fills both a unique niche, and one with very wide appeal. It is worth playing in many senses of the word, but with clear flaws and a lack of polish regarding many of the core ideas.

At the end of every "run" you spend all your shekels on upgrades which can expand the range of classes randomly available to you, provide stat upgrades, or new abilities. There's also a blacksmith and magical rune person that eat your money as well.The goal is to power yourself up to kill the four bosses in the game which reign in four separate areas (since the game is randomly generated, you can generally find them by going far enough in any direction (i.e. up, down, left, right, etc). Posted: July 8, 2014
 "I have lived a rogue's legacy..."	  SO MANY BABIES!	 So you're reading a review about Rogue Legacy? Odds are you either are coming to see if the hype around this game is warranted, or you've seen it was on sale and need that one last push to convince you that your purchase won't be in vain. While a bit lengthy, this review holds everything you could ever want to know before buying. WELL LET ME TELL YOU!!! This game is by far one of the most fun games I've purchased in a long while. I'll start with a synopsis of the game's plot, followed by the pros and cons of the game, and end it with an official rating and some inside info on gameplay.  Just scroll to the end and find my header titled "Gameplay" if all you want to know is "gameplay mechanics please, I don't need story info".	  Synopsis	  You are the heir to a throne occupied by a king who has fallen ill. To what, you don't entirely know. The king has set out on a quest to remedy himself by venturing in to a castle that has been rumored to be haunted for years on the outskirts of his land. Within this castle is the key to curing all sickness. If a hero proves himself worthy to battle through the arduous citadel, they will find themselves with the ultimate power to cure themselves of any ailment. Your father has disappeared. It was rumored he found himself the treasure within and decided to stay with his new found riches. Others believe he fell to the beasts that inhabit the dangerous depths. Regardless of his fate, this prompts your brother, the antagonist of the story, to begin his own journey into the castle and claim the fortune for himself. You play as a generation of heroes, all dedicated to saving the king, and rescuing your brother who also has appeared to be lost. Throughout your exploration of the castle, you stumble across various journal entries, chronicling your brothers advancements. I won't reveal the ending, but I will hint that the castle's riches are far more evil than any monster ever could be. As you begin your journey you find that the castle is most certainly under some type of spell... Every time a traveler enters the cold, unwelcoming halls, the rooms are randomized entirely. No floor plan is ever the same, causing confusion and plenty of surprises for any weary guest. Being a fortress for countless foes inhabiting the keep, your only reference is a map you create as you navigate each room. Moving from area to area, you find that the castle leads out to a haunted forest, a miasma of ghouls, and a crypt of darkness. Of course there is a mighty enemy that dominates each territory. These boss-like creatures are found out eventually to be previous explorers who have fallen victim to the castle's ultimate secret. The further your travels take you, the more accomplished you feel each time. But at what cost? At the end of each life, you reawaken as new kin. A son or daughter to the previous explorer's family. Countless years pass, and you find that entire generations of warriors are dedicated to a pointless cause it would feel. Will your efforts prove fruitless? Will the castle's secrets finally be unlocked? What of the long lost king, and your traitor of a brother? Spoilers:  Play the game. It takes less than 20 hours to beat it no matter how new you are to it. You don't need spoilers <3	  Pros	 - Every new life leads to a highly randomized generation of soldiers, ready to fight your fight. This means that you will be able to constantly explore new play styles, receive new perks, and have a great time laughing at some of the unfortunate traits you receive. - The replay value of this game is through the roof. It's never the same, meaning each playthrough yields a new experience. - New Game + mode is exceptional. Like most games, there are new items, harder enemies, and even the storyline changes in minor ways. - The traits each character inherits that causes them to be unique, on top of their abilities their class grants them, leads to a fantastic character selection that makes each run memorable.  Cons	 - Many have reviewed this game to say that it is too difficult. I will not disagree with the thought that it is difficult, however, I will counter the argument with this: Once you get the momentum rolling, and build your character up a bit, the difficulty is something you enjoy and crave. Building your characters up is far more enjoyable with a real challenge before you. The difficulty that crushes so many is only temporary, as most will not play past the first hour due to frustration. - One major drawback of the game is that the skill tree is too limited and feels pointless at times. Once you've unlocked everything, you spend the rest of the time building small things like health and defense. You no longer have any real goal to aim for, you're simply buffing up your character. This occurs approximately 14-15 hours in, usually just before you defeat the penultimate boss, or clear the third area. A shame as new game + offers so much, yet leaves the skill tree lacking.  Gameplay/Rating	  Controls/Movement	 The game's controls are a bit difficult. As simple as they are, you'll find yourself going out of your way to execute a much more difficult approach to combat, rather than the intended one. An example of this is the "downstrike" ability. You should have the ability to jump over an enemy, and attack below you. However, the attack is too fast, and you end up hurting yourself, by being susceptible to enemies. Instead, now you'll learn that it's best to jump around all over place, narrowly avoiding attacks, and attacking from the side, to avoid damage. Movement does feel very fluid despite its speed, and you are able to manipulate your character well. The additional perks of certain traits lends itself greatly to gameplay, as some characters have the ability to go where others cannot, some are not knocked back by hits, and some are able to send enemies flying.  Items/Skills/Stats	 Cellar Door Games outdid themselves with the items and skills in this game. The various weapons you can find, equipment you can earn, runes that will allow for special techniques or perks, and items that can assist you (or one in particular that horribly ruins you), are all brilliantly put together in this game. As said before, the only area where they fall short, is the stat system. Once you've unlocked everything in the skill tree, you are left to adding to stats while you yearn for more unlockables. The character system that has you choosing between being "The One" and going on a Tron-esque journey into the grid, or having insatiable bowels that cannot stop playing you the song of its people, helps really flesh out this game and give you a feel of infinite scenarios/builds.  Rating/Recommendation On a scale of 0-10 (keeping it simple), I'll give this game a fantastic 9/10. I highly recommend this game to anyone who has even gotten this far in the review. Trust me, it is extremely deserving of your time. Cellar Door Games has created a fantastic way to expend your time. A few honorable mentions are that this game does a great job of helping you truly appreciate the story... The tutorial portion of the game ends up being the last path you take before the end of the game. The dialogue is fantastic and makes you laugh from to time, and of the last statements by the last boss... "Truly I have lived a rogue's legacy"... it definitely struck me. This game is fantastic. I will find myself playing it again and again, restarting a character or continuing off of an accomplished one. Please enjoy this, and see what all the hype is about. Would I invest my time in writing so much if I didn't think this game was freaking amazing?! Thanks for reading. The fact that you did means you and I both are great at wasting time.

Posted: December 5, 2013
												Rogue Legacy is quite a bit more inspired than most indie platformers, combining key elements of Metroidvania, Roguelike, and Bullet Hell games into a charming enough little package. However, a few crucial shortcomings prevent the game from living up to its potential. There's a noticeable lack of overall content that leaves your adventures in the castle feeling samey very quickly in spite of the randomly-generated layout. What's more, to say that this game is grindy is a severe understatement. Still, the core gameplay is hallmarked by tight controls and rewarding challenges, and a randomly-generated castle coupled with two New Game+ modes ensures no small amount of replayability. Rogue Legacy should be approached as an ambitious and addictive little diversion whose indiscretions can be forgiven by its solid fundamentals.

												Rogue Legacy is an amazing platformer.  Controls are tight, tons of loot, a vast array of baddies, and a lot of customization options.However, there isn't much of a story.  Boss battles are fun, but can be quite challenging.  That's good though, as you can get many hours out of this title because of it's challenge and replay value. Posted: July 27, 2013
												Rogue Legacy is a fantastic game that combines the classic action-platforming style (and look) of Castlevania & Ghosts & Ghouls with a modern compulsion based structure that is as clever and innovative as it is challenging.The game is far from easy, designed to be a "Rogue-Like" game where upon each death, you have to start over and delve once again into the randomly generated castle.However, Cellar Door Games have lightened this hardcore feature in a creative and intelligent way through their Lineage System, allowing a sense of advancement and progression in a game fundamentally about perma-death and skill runs.Upon each death, you are asked to choose an heir to your legacy. Your heir inherits the gold collected on your previous runs and can use it to upgrade Castle Components for new classes and permanent benefits, Forge New Weapons and Armor with statistical upgrades and powers and Enchant Runes that slot into each piece of equipment which grant you important skills to customize your character to your play style. All these upgrades carry forward to each heir in succession, slowly growing your legacy and power and allowing you to more quickly dispatch enemies and make more and more progress.Humorous randomly assigned Traits (some cosmetic, some debilitating, some extremely beneficial) keep things fresh and endearingly hilarious on each run. This allows you to stay invested until your skills are good enough that the challenge of the level matches your understanding of the system and you to begin to use strategy to plan our your next assault choosing the hero with the class, traits or spells that would best suit your next run's goals.Secret Areas, Chests and Skill Based Challenges make each new room of the castle an intriguing surprise as you hope for another armor blueprint, magic rune, or pile of gold that will allow you to purchase more upgrades and finally defeat that next ridiculous boss that has haunted you for generations.The game's nostalgia value, smooth, simple controls and delightful humor draw you in, and it's upgrade and advancement system keeps you eagerly playing. The game overall is an impressive, innovative and rewarding title and aside from the difficulty, there is little not to like about this incredible indie game.

												Hooray I finished Rogue Lega- And then I unlocked new game+. This game is just the biggest♥♥♥♥♥♥at the weener conference, but at least it's one that'll give you a fair challenge. This game isn't easy and VERY much one big grindfest, but surprisingly, it didn't even feel like it. You never felt like you were grinding, you were just enjoying the game. It never felt like you were grinding this d- okay I will stop with this metaphor now and get to reviewing each part of the game.Graphics:Like a lot of indie titles, it decides to go for the pixelated graphic style. While I would say I wish some games didn't, it actually adds character to this game. It feels like you're playing an old Castlevania game of some sort. But actually way better. While it is pixelated, it is nicely stylized and actually looks amazing. You can clearly see what's in the background and what's in the front, and in some cases the art style actually adds to the gameplay (like with the paintings). Like I said the art style adds more character to the game, and I don't know how it would look without pixelated graphics, but it surely would lose that characteristic that actually adds to the game.Sound Design:HHHHNNNNNNNNNNGHHHHHHH SWEET LORD MY EARS ARE BLESSED BY THIS GAME. *cough* Sorry for that. It's just that this game is an absolute joy to listen to. The soundtrack is amazing and adds a sense of adventure to the game and clearly seperates the different areas of the castle in the way they feel. During boss battles the background music gives you this sense that something you've trained for is finally paying off (and then you discover you're only 1/5th done). But the real reason my ears love this game are the absolutely amazing sound effects. From coins to spike traps, the sound effects are extremely satisfying to hear and the sound of the coins is actually so satisfying that it makes you want to get more and more AND MORE AND-Gameplay:The gameplay is simplistic. But does that mean it doesn't satisfy? Hell no. The gameplay is just fine and dandy. While it's very simplistic, this actually makes it quite a bit more fun too be honest. No complex combos you have to learn on anything. Just simply smash the buggers with your sword or eventually throw some magic at people.While playing as the character is actually simple, the game is VERY deep in the other parts. From the characters and skills you can unlock to the upgrades you can get, the depth of this game is quite... well, deep. Not to mention that every character plays differently. The Hokage, who is just a machine of destruction who will nearly 1 hit kill everything with the right gear and upgrades to the Spellsword who can use so much magic that melee is just a way for you to recharge mana. Not to mention the traits of each individual character. Most of the traits are quite bad and some can be good sometimes, but it adds to the challenge of the game and the playstyle of the character. Especially when you have Vertigo, good luck in that case.This game is overall great. There are some minor complaints like wizards sometimes being able to shoot through walls for some reason, but it's a definite must-own for everyone who loves this kind of gameplay while still definitely being worth a try for people who usually don't.

Posted: January 24, 2014
												Another game oozing with really smart game design, Rogue Legacy is probably what you’d get if you crossed Castlevania with a “bullet hell” game like Ghouls N’ Ghosts. Like Castlevania, the main objective of Rogue Legacy is to explore a castle and defeat several bosses within it. But what sets Rogue Legacy apart and makes it really fun and interesting is that, when you die - and you will die a lot - you get to choose between 1 of 3 children of the character you were just playing to avenge their parent and explore the castle. Each child may have genetic abnormalities or traits that make the game play differently each time. Some will directly affect gameplay, while others are just for flavor. For example, you may have a child who’s a midget. They’ll have a smaller hitbox and be able to go through small openings, but they may also take more knockback. Or you might have a child who’s colorblind. Then the game is played in black and white until you die again. And each time you die, the layout of the castle is randomly rearranged, so it’s kind of like playing a brand new game each time. You’re also free to swap out skills and equipment to experiment with different playstyles if you’re stuck on a boss. Really cool stuff. On top of that, you’ll inherit your items from your parent when they die, but the game makes you spend the money you inherit on upgrading new items or skills before you reenter the castle. So each time you die, there’s a kind of moment where you think “Crap I died…But now I get to choose a new character and upgrade their items and skills!” A neat mechanic because it makes you never feel overly frustrated when you die. Which is good, because this game is hard. And you’ll die. A lot. I can’t really think of too many negative criticisms of this game, it’s very solid and well designed. Again, not too pretty to look at, but that doesn’t matter to me for a game like this. Maybe the soundtrack was a bit unremarkable, but that’s nitpicking. Check out Rogue Legacy if you can handle a challenge.For more game reviews, check out http://whatisjamesplaying.blogspot.com/

Posted: July 30, 2013
												An absolutely amazing game. Rogue Legacy delivers on all levels. The music brings back memories of Diablo II. The look of the game is definitely classic Super Nintendo Ghouls and Ghosts, however the gameplay has merit in its own right. It does not really play like Ghosts and Goblins or its successor Ghouls and Ghosts, which is not a bad thing. Many different character classes can be unlocked and each class has its own special ability that takes mana. You will find new pieces of armor and runes as you play, which you can purchase after your character's inevitable permanent death. Upon death you will then choose an heir to keep your legacy alive. Each character has its own special traits that can help or hinder you along the way. The runes that you acquire will give your character new abilities or they can do things such as make enemies harder, but also give you more gold.Rogue Legacy is challenging, it will test your prowess. The game features a new game + mode, which makes it even more difficult and allows you to continue upgrading your manor and purchasing new armor and runes even after you have completed the game. The short storyline is good and it will keep you motivated to keep going.

Posted: April 9
												Having already earned all trophies on the PS3 version of Rogue Legacy, today i managed to complete 100% of achievements on the steam version of the game. That in itself should be a testament to how enjoyable the game is, as it was not only one of the very few games that i've bought more than once but one that i've managed to fully complete more than once, with the main reason being that it's just so fun to pick up and play.The combat is enjoyable, difficult, almost bullet-hell like at times, but rewarding and usually fair in my experience. The core concept of the game, having you select a child to play as after death gives each play through that different feel and lends itself to different playstyles. The graphics are nice and clean, the story is comparatively good when compared to the typical rogue-like/lite game and the soundtrack again is pretty nice. Nothing too outstanding in it's own right but it's all packaged together well and the level of challenge available makes the life/death cycle surprisingly enjoyable. It's a game that expects you to die and is setup in a way that failure can still be fun. I'd definitely recommend this game to anyone who enjoys randomly generated indie titles, especially if you enjoy a challenge. It's clear that the devs put a lot into Rogue Legacy and that they respect their playerbase, which is always great to see.

												An excellent Castlevania-style platformer with roguelike elements. I do wish there was a bit more enemy variety (there's a fair number of palette swaps), and some of the rooms show up more often than I'd like, but overall Rogue Legacy is definitely worth a look for platformer fans and roguelike fans alike.

Posted: July 22, 2013
												To put it simply, if you like action/platformer/rpg hybrids in any combination or roguelikes, you'll probably enjoy this game quite a bit.  The tricky part comes when you think about just how muhc you want to play it.If you just want to finish the game a single time, there are not many flaws, all things considered; a very fun, colorful, charming, unique experience awaits you, and you'll have a great time building up your lineage's permanent stat boosts, equipment and enchanment options while you simultaneously build actual skill at playing the game as you discover and suffer through more and more different types of enemies, minibosses and unique room setups.  The bosses are fairly challenging but fun, and  conveniences like the architect which keeps the castle from changing for a price will keep you from ever becoming too frustrated.  Mix in the plethora of classes to try and unique 'afflictions' that your descendants may possess, many of which carry with them both positive and negative aspects, and just a very solid, fun, well-tuned gameplay all around, and what you have is a very solid 8, if not 8.5/10 experience.But then... Spoilers.  There's a New Game + mode.  And from that point... things get a bit different.  Now, you can do EVERYTHING else in the game that wasn't available in the first playthrough in this mode -- collect all the rest of the equipment, earn the last achievements and actually be able to feasibly afford all of the upgrades, chiefly.  But as you venture into this mode and beyond (the game has an infinite NG+ system where every NG+ increases monster strength and gold value drastically) the game's flaws start to become very apparent; Many of the worse afflictions that may have seemed funny or charming the first time become nothing more than annoyances that you'd rather didn't exist; Many of the CLASSES, particularly spellcasters and the treasure-seeking miners, become utterly outclassed and overshadowed by their melee counterparts, especially in NG2+ and higher when critical hits become required to really do damage, and alas, magic cannot crit.  Eventually only Assassins and Barbarians are truly capable to even play as, and many afflictions make gameplay impossible in the higher difficulties, or severely hinder it -- and each time you move up a NG+ number you can never go back without completely wiping your save.  Long story short, the game becomes less and less fun the further you get.Perhaps eventually some of these issues will be patched and smoothed out, but currently, I'd very heartily give you this advice; Do everything you possibly can in the original game (and GET THE CARNIVAL ACHIEVEMENT if you care, before beating the final boss!  I can't stress that enough, if you don't want to pull your hair out!);  In NG+ get ALL the rest of the equipment and enchantments and then when you slay the final boss a second time, move on to a different game.7.5/10

												Well, that was a lot more time than I would have hoped to spend on this game. Now you might see my hours and go "why is this not recommended?" And that's because honestly this game isn't "bad", it's just not a game I can recommend. I picked this game up from a Steam sale because, hey, 2$ for a game is great, right? Well, this game is riddled with issues. Its main gimmick of giving you a new character to go with wears off after you start unlocking more classes (because you need to unlock stuff in order to be able to unlock some of the really good skills) and you find out just how weak many of the classes are. Mages aren't very useful when magic is such a tight resource and get vastly outclassed by spellswords, Liches aren't very useful, and assassins are outclassed pretty much completely by ninjas. Even the best class, the Dragon, is pretty much useful for one thing, killing the 4th boss, which the right spellsword just does better. Basically any time I didn't have a Barbarian, Paladin or Ninja I just felt like I could be doing so much better. And some of the quirks are just awful, such as Vertigo or MP/HP swap. The game restricts your ability to play it with its various character classes and quirks, which you only have a very small amount of control over. While this leaves a lot of variety, it leaves the entire experience inconsistent and pads the game length. And then the bosses just weren't very fun, outside of the final boss. A giant floating eyeball, a floating fire head, a giant slime, is that really the best they could come up with?All around the game is fun when you actually have what you want, but that is so sporadic that the entire game just feels out of your control and much of the game you spend playing inferior characters in the vain hopes of getting enough cash to buy something better.

This is the one feature I didn't like; You can give up a percentage of your gold to lock the castle and keep your progress. It feels like cheating to me. You should have to find all the bosses, not just teleport to them! Despite that, it's a really fun game that will have you hooked. Buy it!

Posted: February 20, 2014
												This is the game for people who like dying both in and out of game.Right off the bat I have to say that this is my current favorite game. Yeah I've played others more, but have I talked about them to the extent that it nearly cost me one friend and the ones who are slightly more tolerant are still rolling their eyes? No. I am almost willing to bet that I have a bounty on my head. "Kill this person!" someone has said. "They won't stop talking about this game!"To make things crazier, the thing I'm willing to risk my own life for also involves a cuss-ton of death. I've literally gotten an achievement for dying so much.  The fact that you will die is a given; the biggest draw of the game is in the very title. This is a story about your legacy. Your lineage. Yes, you have to start at the beginning of the game when you die (albeit with much more power and better items and stuff). But maybe this time your kid will have some cussing useful traits, like not having a pulse in their feet, or a really awesome memory. Of course, they could also have any number of vision problems (which will cuss with you like you won't believe), or maybe they'll be upside down for their entire life. With a good hero, you'll be rooting for them not to die. A bad one practically has you throwing them in front of the monsters.While the "rogue-lite" setup is draw in and of itself, I found myself sticking around for the awful (and by awful I mean hilarious) humor. References abound. Naruto, Skyrim, an internet meme or two. References aren't your thing? The characters you'll come across are among the most sarcastic you'll meet in gaming. None are afraid to openly mock you for being very, very awful at Rogue Legacy. Even the training dummy joins in: "Dost thou even hoist?" he sneers. If sarcasm is also not your thing, it's easy to be delighted by the random things you'll find in your exploration of the dungeons in this game. Jukeboxes, random carnival games, and for those who just literally have no sense of humor, the pieces of a (mostly) serious journal that tell a grim tale when read together.I recommend this to anyone with a lot of time to spare (you'll need it), a mountain of patience, and a love of platformers. A controller is optional (the keyboard controls work well, and some even say they work better, though I disagree). Thinking price-wise, I got this on sale, but would have paid the full price if I knew how much fun I was going to have playing it. The only complaint that I can even vaguely form is that there is no multiplayer/co-op. This is probably a good thing, because if there was I would likely force my friends to play it with me and then they'd hate me even more than they already do.I'm not saying you should get this game, but you should definitely get this game.

												This game puts a very comical spin on permadeath. It's a 2D sidescroller that has very polished graphics, an interesting backdrop, good audio, tons of replayability and loads of fun. You play a knight that is trying to get through the castle to avenge the king. When you die that character is gone however you get to choose between three of your children to succeed you. There is a mix of classes that you have available to you however there is a catch. Most of your children will have a "trait" or two that can range anywhere from dementia, far-sighted, ADHD, to being color blind. That adds a quirkiness and charm to the game that makes it unique. When you die however you retain the gold that you collected during your last character's life and use that to purchase upgrades making it easier for those that come after. The catch here is that when you enter the castle again you forfeit your gold to the keeper of the castle gates: Charon. (Later on you can research keeping a percentage of your gold that you can add to the next playthrough and spend on upgrades). Overall a quirky game that is full of polish, replayability and fun. Definite recommendation.

Posted: February 20, 2014
												This is the game for people who like dying both in and out of game.Right off the bat I have to say that this is my current favorite game. Yeah I've played others more, but have I talked about them to the extent that it nearly cost me one friend and the ones who are slightly more tolerant are still rolling their eyes? No. I am almost willing to bet that I have a bounty on my head. "Kill this person!" someone has said. "They won't stop talking about this game!"To make things crazier, the thing I'm willing to risk my own life for also involves a cuss-ton of death. I've literally gotten an achievement for dying so much.  The fact that you will die is a given; the biggest draw of the game is in the very title. This is a story about your legacy. Your lineage. Yes, you have to start at the beginning of the game when you die (albeit with much more power and better items and stuff). But maybe this time your kid will have some cussing useful traits, like not having a pulse in their feet, or a really awesome memory. Of course, they could also have any number of vision problems (which will cuss with you like you won't believe), or maybe they'll be upside down for their entire life. With a good hero, you'll be rooting for them not to die. A bad one practically has you throwing them in front of the monsters.While the "rogue-lite" setup is draw in and of itself, I found myself sticking around for the awful (and by awful I mean hilarious) humor. References abound. Naruto, Skyrim, an internet meme or two. References aren't your thing? The characters you'll come across are among the most sarcastic you'll meet in gaming. None are afraid to openly mock you for being very, very awful at Rogue Legacy. Even the training dummy joins in: "Dost thou even hoist?" he sneers. If sarcasm is also not your thing, it's easy to be delighted by the random things you'll find in your exploration of the dungeons in this game. Jukeboxes, random carnival games, and for those who just literally have no sense of humor, the pieces of a (mostly) serious journal that tell a grim tale when read together.I recommend this to anyone with a lot of time to spare (you'll need it), a mountain of patience, and a love of platformers. A controller is optional (the keyboard controls work well, and some even say they work better, though I disagree). Thinking price-wise, I got this on sale, but would have paid the full price if I knew how much fun I was going to have playing it. The only complaint that I can even vaguely form is that there is no multiplayer/co-op. This is probably a good thing, because if there was I would likely force my friends to play it with me and then they'd hate me even more than they already do.I'm not saying you should get this game, but you should definitely get this game.

												Rogue Legacy is an amazing Rogue-like experience and I highly recommend it, assuming you like rogue-like games.You are going to die.  A lot.  Period.  Infact, even if you play perfectly, to progress, you MUST die.  If that bothers you, you do NOT like rogue-likes and should probably not play this as a result.This game has a great learning curve but you need to be good at 'platforming' games like Mario, Sonic and Megaman (to name a few) to be good at this game.  Your main goal is to collect as much gold on each castle clear as you can (assuming you live through the entire castle) so when you die, you can purchase much needed character progression upgrades which will also be represented as 1 level per upgrade invested.This leads to character progression as long as your not dying before you collect a decent sum of gold.  The controls are tight and precise (I use the xbox 360 wired controller on my PC) and when you die, its often because you messed up.  The enemies start out very easy and get progressively harder in each wing of the castle not to mention that there is a New Game Plus mode as well.  In fact, you can progress the castle in NG+ modes as far as you want to.  Its up to you.If your a fan of Rogue-likes, this game is a must have and I highly recommend it!

Posted: April 9
												Having already earned all trophies on the PS3 version of Rogue Legacy, today i managed to complete 100% of achievements on the steam version of the game. That in itself should be a testament to how enjoyable the game is, as it was not only one of the very few games that i've bought more than once but one that i've managed to fully complete more than once, with the main reason being that it's just so fun to pick up and play.The combat is enjoyable, difficult, almost bullet-hell like at times, but rewarding and usually fair in my experience. The core concept of the game, having you select a child to play as after death gives each play through that different feel and lends itself to different playstyles. The graphics are nice and clean, the story is comparatively good when compared to the typical rogue-like/lite game and the soundtrack again is pretty nice. Nothing too outstanding in it's own right but it's all packaged together well and the level of challenge available makes the life/death cycle surprisingly enjoyable. It's a game that expects you to die and is setup in a way that failure can still be fun. I'd definitely recommend this game to anyone who enjoys randomly generated indie titles, especially if you enjoy a challenge. It's clear that the devs put a lot into Rogue Legacy and that they respect their playerbase, which is always great to see.

												This game is pretty amazing, defining of the rogue-like genre and packed with hours of fun. Raiding the castle is its strong suite, and you'll go through the randomly generated castle rooms time and time again and have a blast doing so. The main bosses are fun, excluding the final battle, and the optional end-game bosses. The issue with the final bosses final form and the end-game optional bosses is that they mainly utilize pseudo difficulty. They're meant to feel super hard, but in reality are not. By the time you defeat them, rather than feeling like you're overcome an obstacle, you're thinking "thank goodness I did not get too many undodgeable knife cycles", or that you didn't take a hit you couldn't have possibly avoided. The RNG makes the fight, it can be very easy with good RNG, or a nightmare with stacks of attacks you cannot dodge(Unless you're the right class).All in all, still a great game, but the last 5 bosses(excluding the final brothers fight) all leave much to be desired. If anything, you can learn how RNG can turn a fight that's supposed to be difficult, into a grind for the right RNG. Another con is that in the late game (NG++ and on) which class you are determines whether or not you'll be able to achomplish anything. And the gold collecting class becomes completely useless. You can also unlock a dragon class, but in NG+, it's completely useless and just wastes your roster slots and increases the odds you get a useless class.I know I mostly sang the flaws of this game, but I still highly suggest it. It's because I enjoy the game so much that I harp so heavily on the flaws that it does have. If these issues were resolved, it'd go from a good game to a great game. But I still reccomend this game to those who are a fan of the genre.

Posted: April 20, 2016
The good+Big challenge, built around good controls and varied enemy attacks+The offspring mechanic is an interesting element in the game. The descendants' traits can have hilarious visual/sound effects, and positive/negative stat modifiers+The classes are pretty much well balanced considering their skillsets, and they allow different playstyles+The combination of offspring traits, classes, and procedurally created castles makes room for a highly-replayable, non repetitive game. This expands further with new game plus +Enemy designs are great, both mechanics and visuals. The whole game has a good, consistent artstyle+Armor and rune upgrades allow customization of playstyle+Character upgrades, in combination with the architect, allow for slow climbing the game, something ideal for less skilled playersThe bad-Some irregularities in player's movement (dash has zero effect if knocked back; some weird bugs while moving towards spikes)-The game doesn't add much to the genre, all in allI wasn't positive on Rogue Legacy from the beggining - at one point while playing this game I absolutely hated it. I thought grinding was necessary since I kept dying without getting a sense of advancement, and I absolutely despised the idea of a game that involved grinding in its gameplay. After some time playing I realized I needed to adapt to the game, which meant actually dodging enemy attacks and attacking safely. Before long, I was doing room clears and beating bosses all to the final boss. In that, my initial disgust with the game was based on a misunderstanding on my part.All this is to say Rogue Legacy is the same formula of any hard-as-nails game: there's no grinding involved if you git gud. You can finish a first playthrough without grinding at all, just dying once in a while to spend all that gold from bosses and room clears. At that, the game's design is quite inclusive, since you can either turtle your way in by using the architect to reach and beat the bosses, or you can become aware of the enemies' patterns and dodge like a ballerina while hitting fast - either playstyle is valid. A lot of people might hate the first style (rightfully), so to fully enjoy Rogue Legacy you either have to be quite skilled or have the patience to creep your way up. You could say it's a gitgud or gohome kind of game, and maybe that's its greatest fault.A very important element in this game are the remixed bosses, which are its crown jewel in my opinion. Beating them involves complete understanding of the classes, jumps and dashes, and also understanding of the bosses' environments and the bosses' movements. It's a gameplay element which requires fine execution, observation and judgement as a proof of mastery, and it's something really enjoyable to see implemented.The bottom lineA tough, enjoyable 2D platformer heavily inspired by classic Castlevania, with a fun trait+offspring system and some replayability.

												First let me get this outta the way, this is in no way a Rogue-like game at all, it's as much of one as is any old school NES game like Mario or Contra, what is it then? An Action/Platformer type with some RPG lite elements mixed in (later it becomes a stupid as hell Bullet-Hell dodging game), it's very grindy in nature having you repeat the same things over and over again to gaining money little by little so you can strengthen you guy with unlocks to make the game easier, that's pretty much the game, its quite shallow with only 5 bosses total and the enemies are all re-skins with the same patterns/move-sets that you will learn soon enough. It's also clearly only balanced for your first and second playthrough, then the Dev's just went all lazy on it and pulled a Jay Wilson "And then we doubled It" (This is when it turns into a stupid Bullet-Hell dodging game, so never go beyond NG+1).All in all it's still a really fun game for two playthoughs, the first clear will probably take you 8 hours and the second another 3, so 11~ hours of fun for 15 bucks is great deal IMO, just be prepared to do lots of money farming which is very repetitive.Tip time:The Dragon class sucks balls, do not unlock it ever because it will take spots in your gene pool and screw your RNG and make you made, other classes that suck are the Miner/Spelunker and to a lesser extent Lich/Lich King class, so try and avoid them but you can't really because they♥♥♥♥♥♥block you from other Castle upgrades.As I said earlier do not move onto New Game+2 until you have every achievement unlocked and have farmed up a storm getting your self up around level 250 or higher, because once you hit NG+2 it becomes stupid hard and no fun, you'll just end up rushing to boss rooms and skipping everything else, and there is no going back.Upgrades you should focus on making your character stronger and more survivable, don't waste money on the fluff stuff, Attack Power > Health > Crit > Mana > Magic Dmg for example.

content:
Posted: May 26, 2015
												I started playing Rogue Legacy on a whim one day when none of my co-op friends were online and immediately got sucked into it. I really like pretty much everything about this game and would recommend it for pretty much everyone.The gameplay is solid, if you like 2D sidescrolling games. The combat is fluid, and the enemies are diverse. The different classes you unlock also give you some diversity in gameplay style and allow you to pick what you prefer (tanky vs fast vs magic) I really enjoy the presentation as well as the art style is clean and congruous, but they aren't afraid to play with things for fun.What really sets Rogue Legacy apart though is the character selection. As with a proper rogue-like, you will be dying a lot. Like, a lot. And once you do, you are giving the option of picking between 3 successors, with random rolled characteristics. The traits are interesting and add a really fun element to the game. I don't want to go into detail about what they do because it's fun to discover them, but it's a nice design that keeps the game fresh.Speaking of rogue-likes, this is how they should be. You expect to die constantly, but I rarely find it frustrating because that's part of the experience. The goal isn't to finish everything in one life, it's to live long enough to collect loot and gear to unlock permanent upgrades for your lineage. Thus, each attempt gives you a slightly better chance at getting farther the next time. The scaling works really well too. You will slow creep farther and farther into deeper areas, sometimes without even realizing right away that you're making progress. I'm finding that balance to be well executed as I can reasonably proceed to harder areas around the time I'm starting to find the area I've been playing in too easy.This is a game that it's easy to get sucked into. I often find myself playing for an hour or two longer than I planned on because I've unlocked something new and say "just one more run before I quit" several times in a row. It's fun, amusing, challenging, and gives you something to work towards. You really can't ask for more than that.

												Rogue Legacy is like an indie version of Castlevania: Symphony of the Night.  The game is polished for what it is.  The intro starts as you're a knight that kills an evil king in a castle.  Flash forward to present where you play as the son of that knight that goes into this castle to find out what happened to your father.  Each time you die in the game you play as the son or daughter of the previous knight.  Each generation has different traits and character types that change how you play the game.  The castle layout changes each time you die and enter the castle.  Also, when you pick a new heir to go questing you get the inheritance money of the previous knight which you can use to purchase new swords, armors, or build your own castle to unlock power-ups and new knight types.  This game is loads of fun and has great replayability.  It's a steal at $5 and worth the regular price.

												I love this game so, so much. This is probably one of my Top 20 games, ever.I love Castlevania, I love procedurally generated games, and I love roguelikes. This game is a fantastic mashing-together of all three. I really don't feel that they could have integrated these three genres any better.The character progression and growth feels amazing. I suppose it's technically possible to beat the end boss on your first non-tutorial life, but it feels exactly as horrible and impossble a task as it should, with no powers, wealth, or weapons to help you out. As you get the hang of the game and learn its secrets, you unlock more and more powers to pass on to future generations, and eventually manage to barely scrape past bosses you've been pouring incredible amounts of time into. It's refreshing for a modern game to demand this much of you, and it's a lot of fun to take the challenge.Protip: If you buy this, it's playable and fun without a controller, but it's so much better with one. The controls really feel natural on a controller, which is something that I feel is pretty rare. The characters' movements feel tight, but also really fluid, which is something I've really only experienced previously with Super Meat Boy.At the time I'm recommending this, the game's on sale for less than $5. This game is worth so much more than that. It felt like a steal for $15. If there's ever any DLC for this, I'm impulse-buying it.Buy this game. You won't regret it.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												Rogue Legacy is a semi-Rogue-like Metroid/Castlevania-style 2D action/platformer, where you explore a changing mansion and try to clear the enemies and treasure out of it. Death is permanent, but when you die, your offspring take your place, and with the money you collected in your last run, you can buy items that will help with every future attempt.Rogue Legacy is a difficult game, and you will die many times as you play. The nice thing is that when you die, the castle layout changes, meaning that you won't keep dying to the same stupid trap. You do lose all of your money when you re-enter the castle, so you'll have to purchase upgrades with only the money you got on your last run, So, if you well on your run, you can buy a nice upgrade. If you do poorly, just enter the castle again and hope for a better layout. So, while this game is pretty difficult, it's not nearly as frustrating as a lot of other tough games are, even on those early runs where you die without getting anything at all.If course, the gimmick of this game is that each different hero has different traits that alter gameplay. It's funny, but doesn't significantly change things most of the time.I played with an XBox controller, and the controls worked pretty well for me. The music is solid. The graphics are pretty nice, though some of the filters that certain traits add get very annoying.If this sort of game looks interesting to you, definitely pick it up. I've had a lot of fun with Rogue Legacy. Inexperienced gamers may have a difficult time getting very far, though.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												I should dislike this game.  I should hate it.  You die... a LOT.  You lose the money you have collected every life.  Your character changes every life.  Sometimes the layout of the castle is downright obtuse and painful.  Sometimes everything seems to be against you.  And yet, this is an awesome game that if you stick with it will have you coming back for more over and over again.While everything can sometimes feel like it's against you dying is always your fault.  You either were not quick enough or didn't plan ahead or was too desperate to reach the chest.Respawning is quick and provides choice, will you be a vampire lich who leaches health from your kills or a giant mage?  There are many choices here all with their pros and cons.  And there are a multitude of ways to spend your money, do you focus on equipment and runes or skills?  (The skill tree is huge)  Combat is satisfying and the enemies are varied.  The boss battles are tough and rewarding, mini bosses are also a challenge.  There is a lot to explore and the randomized castle and dungeon layouts keeps things fresh.  You can't do anything by rote, you are always challenged and trying out new things.But the game isn't without issues.  Losing your remaining money everytime you enter the castle is downright annoying (you can lower the % amount via costly upgrades but it's still painful to lose 1000 coins).  Upgrades can cost too much which makes you sometimes feel like it's a grind.  Money isn't as plentiful as it could be and the randomized layouts mean that you can't go straight to tougher areas directly.  You can lock the layout but at a cost to how much money you recieve which negates the value.  It can also be hard to find the right balance between your character and equipment and sometimes the quirky traits your character has means that you just wish they would die so you can respawn (what value is there to everything being upside down?). It's whimsical, it's challenging, and it even has a decent story that gets really interesting towards the end. I think its greatest fault is its potentially frustrating beginning though. The short tutorial is fine, but unlike another famous rogue-like platformer Spelunky, you probably won't have a "fair chance" at completing even the early content until you grind for a certain number of persistent upgrades. Many rogue-likes and rouge-like hybrids always start you off the same way and just force you to use your skill, wits, and luck to complete any given run. Even though you certainly need wits and skill to get you through Rogue Legacy, you can progressively and permenantly soften the difficulty of different sections by collecting gold, equipment, character classes, and runes. This is great for those who find rogue-likes in general too hard for their tastes, but it does mean that you may occasionally hit difficulty spikes that make you feel like you have to grind before you can tackle further content. (I'd say that each area is roughly tuned to increments of 25 character / upgrade levels. So you probably won't complete your first run of the game until you are about level 75 - 100.) Still, as more stuff unlocks I feel the game gets progressively better and more "fair", so it's worth sticking through the rough bits for the fun bits if you have the patience. By the time you unlock everything, the world is your oyster in terms of how you want to customize yourself for the challenges that still lie ahead.

Posted: December 23, 2013
												Rogue Legacy is a semi-Rogue-like Metroid/Castlevania-style 2D action/platformer, where you explore a changing mansion and try to clear the enemies and treasure out of it. Death is permanent, but when you die, your offspring take your place, and with the money you collected in your last run, you can buy items that will help with every future attempt.Rogue Legacy is a difficult game, and you will die many times as you play. The nice thing is that when you die, the castle layout changes, meaning that you won't keep dying to the same stupid trap. You do lose all of your money when you re-enter the castle, so you'll have to purchase upgrades with only the money you got on your last run, So, if you well on your run, you can buy a nice upgrade. If you do poorly, just enter the castle again and hope for a better layout. So, while this game is pretty difficult, it's not nearly as frustrating as a lot of other tough games are, even on those early runs where you die without getting anything at all.If course, the gimmick of this game is that each different hero has different traits that alter gameplay. It's funny, but doesn't significantly change things most of the time.I played with an XBox controller, and the controls worked pretty well for me. The music is solid. The graphics are pretty nice, though some of the filters that certain traits add get very annoying.If this sort of game looks interesting to you, definitely pick it up. I've had a lot of fun with Rogue Legacy. Inexperienced gamers may have a difficult time getting very far, though.

												I should dislike this game.  I should hate it.  You die... a LOT.  You lose the money you have collected every life.  Your character changes every life.  Sometimes the layout of the castle is downright obtuse and painful.  Sometimes everything seems to be against you.  And yet, this is an awesome game that if you stick with it will have you coming back for more over and over again.While everything can sometimes feel like it's against you dying is always your fault.  You either were not quick enough or didn't plan ahead or was too desperate to reach the chest.Respawning is quick and provides choice, will you be a vampire lich who leaches health from your kills or a giant mage?  There are many choices here all with their pros and cons.  And there are a multitude of ways to spend your money, do you focus on equipment and runes or skills?  (The skill tree is huge)  Combat is satisfying and the enemies are varied.  The boss battles are tough and rewarding, mini bosses are also a challenge.  There is a lot to explore and the randomized castle and dungeon layouts keeps things fresh.  You can't do anything by rote, you are always challenged and trying out new things.But the game isn't without issues.  Losing your remaining money everytime you enter the castle is downright annoying (you can lower the % amount via costly upgrades but it's still painful to lose 1000 coins).  Upgrades can cost too much which makes you sometimes feel like it's a grind.  Money isn't as plentiful as it could be and the randomized layouts mean that you can't go straight to tougher areas directly.  You can lock the layout but at a cost to how much money you recieve which negates the value.  It can also be hard to find the right balance between your character and equipment and sometimes the quirky traits your character has means that you just wish they would die so you can respawn (what value is there to everything being upside down?).  Allowing you to stockpile more money would be a definite improvement and perhaps having the castle and dungeons larger.  Letting you warp directly to previously found areas would also be a plus grinding through the main castle everytime can be a drag.Overall this is a very fun game with few downsides but you have to stick at it and get past the initial difficulty curve.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2014
												This game is a very good platformer with Roguelike elements and a lot of bullet-dodging. You enter a castle which is randomized each time, with areas generally close to the same locations: Castle (easy part) at the entrance, the Forest (a bit harder) to the left, the Tower (hard) above the Castle section, and the Dungeon (hardest part) below the castle section. A boss guards each area, are not randomized, and have bullet-hell patterns. Once those are defeated, the door to the final boss is unlocked and you can finish the game.This game is really hard, as are most Roguelikes and games that are inspired by Roguelikes. It features perma-death (you die once and it's over) which adds to an already challenging game, although you can "lock down" the castle so that it will have the same layout as last time, for a percentage of your gold. Also, any bosses you kill, stay dead on subsequent playthroughs, so once you defeat all four bosses, you can keep challenging the final boss even without locking the castle down.After your inevitable death, your heir will take up the mantle. You choose between three characters with randomized names, classes, and traits. Some traits are good, most are bad. There's some funny ones such as IBS (every time you jump, you fart), ones that mess with the screen such as Vertigo (play the game upside down), crippling ones such as CIP (can't see your HP), and very beneficial ones such as Eid. Mem. (see the locations of enemies and chests in visited rooms even when you leave). Traits boost the replayability of this game a ton, and most of them are fun, except for two of them which I will get to in a minute.You will also be able to dull the sharp edge of the difficulty and the RNG by upgrading your manor. Basically, you spend gold you collect in the castle on new, stronger classes, better starting stats, and things of that nature. You will also be able to find new equipment and skills to take with you: up to 5 skills can be equipped at once (dash, double-jump, vampirism, etc).The game also has tons of really fun things in it. There's a diary you can read that help the storyline, often lampshading itself. There's minigames where you have to hit all the targets. There's rooms you can find that will show previous games that were developed by the makers of this game. There's even a jukebox that can be found where you can listen to all of the game's soundtrack, though sadly the music you choose does not remain when you leave the room. For the challenge gamer, there's the Fairy Chest Challenges as well, where you must complete a room under specific conditions to get a Fairy Chest. The Fairy Chest always contains something good, like equipment or stat increases.Now for the bad. Those two traits I listed earlier that are not fun? That would be Far-Sighted and Near-Sighted. This game seems to be optimized for high-end video cards, not processing power, so the game is supposed to run at 60 fps. For me, it runs at 20 ~ 30 fps, and there is no way to change any of the graphical options. Far- and Near-Sighted traits slow this down to a crawl of less than 5 fps, as the blur effects it creates to block your vision demand high resources from your video card.In fact, the only real complaint I have about this awesome game is that it may not run at full speed for you, and apart from upgrading your video card, there's nothing you can do about it. Hopefully this will get fixed in the near future. I would play this game a lot more if it ran at full speed. On the other hand, it may make the game a bit easier for some, since everything is half-speed (which is still playable; I thought that was the normal speed... the game runs pretty fast at 60 fps).If you like Spelunky or you like games where you must dodge a lot of bullets, I strongly recommend this purchase, even if you don't have a powerful video card. It has tons of replay value and lots of content to offer even after you beat the game.

content:
Posted: July 22, 2013
												So, eventually I really liked the game, or maybe I just got into the ”not giving up now” mode. TL;DR in bottom. :)After almost 16 hours I finally killed the last boss, having died 183 times, reached level 117 and unlocked a bunch of gear and stats. After this I can continue on New Game+, but to be honest it’s enough for now. :) The game is a platformer where you are tasked with avenging your family (I think) and with your sword and mighty legs of jumping-really-high, you set out into a randomly generated castle. In the beginning both you and your character will be horrible, not getting very far into the castle or getting a lot of loot or money out of it. But for each try you will dodge a bit better, hit a bit harder, take another punch and walk out rich. Eventually you will find the first boss and mightily die like a scrub again.As you level and reach each a new area, you will feel severely underdressed and weak once again, and each area release upgraded versions of the bullet hell monsters or fast monsters or tough monsters from the last area, forcing you to improve and learn their new sets of attack patterns.Each time you die, you get to choose a new randomly generated heir to continue the quest, and depending on what traits and class you play as you have different bonuses, spells and detriments.Your new heir will keep the collected gold from your previous life and will be able to upgrade his/her stats or purchase new equipment for the next generations, you also have a choice of “locking” the castle so you can try to kill any boss again without having to fight your way there again.Right, so the game is good, but also extremely unfair, many times you will find that the camera is too zoomed in, too many monsters shoot through walls and you just don’t have enough space to dodge the 15 bullets that are shot from off-screen. Each of these examples pretty much guaranteeing you to take a lot of damage. All enemies deal a lot of damage, so what you got to do is be fast on the dodging and killing, but if you have no space to dodge, you can’t dodge. And health is often far between.Not only that, if you touch an enemy with anything other than your sword, you will also take damage. This is especially a problem when fighting bosses that take up 1/3rd of the screen, them moving after you so you have to constantly run away, dodge whatever attacks they use and at the same time turn around so your sword hits in the right direction.Anyway, I digress. Much like Dark Souls, it’s a hard game, but if you stick with it you will get better and will probably enjoy the game. But if you are fast on giving up and dislike dying. This will probably not be for you. That said, it’s not as deep or rewarding as Dark Souls, so if you haven’t played that yet. Please, I implore you, do buy it, it’s worth its weight in gold.Here’s a link for it: Graphics are alright, you probably won’t be blown away by the pixel graphics, but it’s certainly not the worst game I have seen.Music is alright, nothing special though.Technically it worked fine, I can’t remember anything bad happening. Though apparently it doesn’t work on Windows 8 yet, so if you have upgraded to that, you should probably wait until it’s officially supported.Right, closing words. It’s a fun and very challenging/unfair platformer with well working mechanics and a fun gimmick. Again, if you dislike dying and grinding to improve your skill and your characters stats, this is probably not for you. However if you are fine with this and want to be challenged (and superchallenged in new game+/++) then this will definitely fit your taste I think.If you have any further questions or comments, please write them in the comments or send me a message. Have a great day! :)

content:
Posted: July 4, 2014
												A fun, procedural rogue-lite, rouge-like, whatever you what to call it.  The randomization of rooms and enemies is well-done, despite the different zones sharing a ton of similarities with the big difference being a coat of paint.  Rogue Legacy also controls really tight, even when you're triple-jumping or flying around the screen with about a dozen enemies crowding around you.  Since you're going to spend most of the game jumping and dodging, good controls are extremely important.The big push of the game, playing as your offspring with different traits, actually is a bit of a letdown.  All characters have the same basic controls and models and share most of the same skills.  Playing as a mage character will involve a lot of the same running, jumping, and sword-swinging as a knight, just with a few minor differences.  The character traits are mostly a mixed bag, with a decent bit of them being one-off things you try once (like vertigo) and never bother with it again.  Some are useful, but more often than not you're going to end up picking the heir with the least negative traits rather than any with a particularly cool effect.Enemies are heavily re-skinned in Rogue Legacy, you'll be fighting same 8-12 enemies most of the game.  This doesn't really bother me since the gampelay is smooth and controls so well and combat is more of a mortal affair where enemies and the player character can both die rather quickly.  Then there's the bosses, easily the worst part of the game for me.  They're not even original enemies, just the same ones you fight over and over but much bigger.  That's the not bad part though.  The actual boss fights are mostly bullet hell sequences when you have to avoid twenty other things going on, dodging the huge boss, and trying to fight all the while.  It's quite annoying to fall onto one of a half-dozen floating spike balls or twenty lingering flames and die while jumping frantically to avoid a boss.  All five bosses in the game have this type of gimmick and they're more frustrating than entertaining.Rogue Legacy is also a bit on the bland side visually.  The character art and backgrounds are perfunctory and that's it.  Music is catchy but not particularly memorable.While it seems I spent most of the review nit-picking about the game, I greatly enjoyed most of my playthough.  The most important aspect of this sort the game, the gameplay, is really good.  The progression system is pretty rewarding and just exploring the castle is fun.  I'd definitely recommend it to anyone that enjoys 2-D platformers or fans of the traditional Castlevanias.
